questions.text: Which of the following is NOT considered a secondary stabilizer of the knee?
questions.explanation:
Static Stabilizers (Primary stabilizers)

Dynamic Stabilizers (Secondary stabilizers)
  • Fibrous capsule
  • Ligamentum patellae
  • Tibial collateral or medial ligament
  • Fibular collateral or lateral ligament
  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Posterior cruciate ligament (Option D)
  • Arcuate popliteal ligament
  • Quadriceps femoris (Option B ruled out)
  • Popliteus (Option A ruled out)
  • Biceps femoris
  • Semitendinosus
  • Semimembranosus (Option C ruled out)
  • Plantaris
  • Gastrocnemius
  • Sartorius

questions.text: A 25-year-old football player presents with severe knee pain after sustaining a twisting injury during a game. On examination, there is swelling and instability. Lachman test is positive, and the valgus stress test at 30 degrees of knee flexion reveals significant instability. Which structure is NOT injured in a clinical setting of O'Donoghue's triad?

A 25-year-old male basketball player presents with knee instability following a non-contact pivoting injury. You perform the anterior drawer test with the patient’s knee flexed to 90° in the supine position, but there is minimal anterior translation of the tibia. However, the Lachman test shows increased anterior tibial translation with no firm endpoint. What is the reason behind the difference in the degree of tibial translational anteriorly between the two clinical tests?

options.label: A
options.text: The anterior drawer test is more reliable for ACL injuries.

options.label: B
options.text: The Lachman test isolates the ACL better by minimizing hamstring influence

options.label: C
options.text: The anterior drawer test was performed incorrectly.

options.label: D
options.text: The patient likely has a partial PCL tear affecting the anterior drawer test.

questions.correct_answer: B. The Lachman test isolates the ACL better by minimizing hamstring influence

questions.text: A 28-year-old soccer player presents with a history of knee injury after feeling a 'pop' during a twisting motion on a slightly flexed knee while playing. He developed immediate swelling and pain in the knee. On examination, the Lachman test is positive. MRI confirms an anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tear. Which of the following is the gold standard imaging modality for diagnosing his condition?
questions.explanation:
Imaging Modality

Use

Sensitivity

X-ray (Option A ruled out)

Detect fractures (femur, tibia)

Moderate

MRI

Assess ligament injuries

~100%

CT (Option B ruled out)

Identify subtle fractures

High for fractures

Treatment

Goal

Notes

Non-operative

Minimize instability via rehabilitation

Activity modification essential

ACL Reconstruction

Stabilize joint, restore kinematics

Grafts: Hamstring/patella tendon

Stepwise Rehabilitation

Improve range, strength, proprioception

Key for post-op recovery

Return to Sports

Gradual return after 9-12 months

Pivoting sports are the highest risk

Injury Prevention Programs

Reduce primary/re-injury risk (e.g., PEP program)

Proven effective in soccer players

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision where his knee struck the dashboard. He reports immediate pain and swelling in the knee. On examination, the posterior sag sign is positive. What is the most likely mechanism of his injury?

options.label: B
options.text: Direct blow to the anterior tibia

options.label: D
options.text: Valgus stress applied to the knee

questions.correct_answer: B. Direct blow to the anterior tibia
questions.explanation:
Test

Method

Indication

Posterior Sag Sign

Observe from the side with knees at 90°, feet resting on the couch, for posterior sag of the tibia.

Reliable for PCL damage.

Drawer Test

Shift the leg forwards and backwards with the knee at 90° and the hamstrings relaxed.

Assesses anterior/posterior stability.

Lachman Test

Assess anteroposterior glide with knee flexed 15-20°.

More reliable for instability.

Quadriceps Active Test

Confirms posterior cruciate ligament insufficiency.

Confirms PCL insufficiency.

questions.text: A 22-year-old athlete presents with a knee injury sustained during a basketball game. He reports immediate swelling and difficulty bearing weight on the affected leg. Physical examination shows a positive Lachman test, indicating increased posterior translation of the tibia. If imaging reveals a partial tear of the PCL, what is the most appropriate management for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Immediate surgical reconstruction of the PCL

options.label: C
options.text: Application of a knee immobilizer and rest for 6 weeks

options.label: D
options.text: Open reduction and internal fixation of the ligament

questions.correct_answer: A. Non-operative management with physical therapy
questions.explanation:
Imaging Type

Findings

X-rays

May show avulsion fractures at PCL insertion on the posterior tibia; stress X-rays visualize posterior translation.

MRI

Gold standard for PCL diagnosis; provides detailed ligament images and detects partial tears.

Treatment Type

Indications

Focus

Non-Operative (Option A)

Isolated PCL injuries, especially in low-demand patients.

Quadriceps strengthening, regain range of motion.

Operative (Option B ruled out)

Patients with persistent instability, functional limitations, or significant bony avulsions.

PCL reconstruction or open reduction and fixation for avulsions.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with knee pain and reports that he feels a "catching" sensation during movement after a recent sports injury. On examination, there is localized tenderness along the joint line, and he experiences difficulty fully extending the knee. Which of the following clinical features is most characteristic of a meniscal tear?

options.label: B
options.text: Pain on passive extension of the knee

options.label: C
options.text: Locking of the knee during movement

questions.correct_answer: C. Locking of the knee during movement
questions.explanation:
Symptom/ Feature

Description

Pain

Localized to the joint line, particularly medial; worsens with activities stressing the meniscus.

Swelling

Delayed onset, usually hours after injury; presents as effusion. (Option A ruled out)

Mechanical Symptoms
  • Locking: Difficulty fully extending the knee; suggests "bucket-handle" tear. (Option C)
  • Catching: Sensation of knee getting stuck, indicating loose fragment.
  • Giving Way: Knee buckling during twisting movements, suggesting instability.

Examination Findings
  • Tenderness: Localized along the joint line, typically medial.
  • Limited Extension: Difficulty achieving full knee extension.
  • Quadriceps Wasting: Possible in chronic cases.
  • Special Tests: Clinical tests (McMurray's, Apley's, Thessaly) assist diagnosis; MRI is the gold standard.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the clinic with knee pain following a twisting injury while playing football. On examination, the patient exhibits localized tenderness along the medial joint line, and the examiner suspects a meniscal tear. Which of the following clinical tests would provide the highest diagnostic accuracy for detecting a meniscal tear in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Test Name

Procedure Description

Positive Sign

Reliability

McMurray's Test

Knee is flexed; examiner stabilizes while rotating the leg. Knee is slowly extended with maintained rotation.

Palpable or audible click during extension.

Not highly reliable; low sensitivity and specificity. (Option A ruled out)

Thessaly Test

Patient stands on the affected leg with the knee flexed at 20 degrees; twists the body while maintaining knee flexion.

Medial or lateral joint line pain or locking sensation.

High diagnostic accuracy (95%); low false-positive/negative rates. (Option C)

Apley's Test

Patient lies prone with knee flexed at 90 degrees; the examiner applies compression (Apley's Grinding Test) or distraction (Apley's Distraction Test) during tibia rotation.


 

Pain with compression suggests meniscal tear; pain with distraction suggests ligament damage.

Not specified; results depend on specific findings. (Options B & D ruled out)

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with knee pain following a twisting injury while playing football. On examination, he exhibits joint line tenderness, effusion, and a limited range of motion. An MRI confirms a meniscal tear. Which of the following statements regarding the management of his condition is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Total meniscectomy is preferred to prevent future complications.

options.label: B
options.text: Conservative treatment includes immobilization and complete rest.

options.label: C
options.text: Meniscal repair is a suitable option for tears in the vascularized peripheral zone.

options.label: D
options.text: X-rays are definitive for diagnosing meniscal injuries.

questions.correct_answer: C. Meniscal repair is a suitable option for tears in the vascularized peripheral zone.
questions.explanation:
Treatment Type

Indications

Management

Conservative Treatment

First-line for non-locked joints; small tears in vascular zone

RICE (rest, ice, compression, elevation), NSAIDs, physical therapy focused on range of motion and strengthening (Option B ruled out)

Operative Treatment

Considered when:

The knee is locked due to a displaced meniscal tear.

Conservative treatment has failed, and mechanical symptoms (like locking or catching) continue.

Surgical options include:

Meniscal Repair: Suture torn edges in vascular zone; promotes healing. (Option C)

Partial Meniscectomy: Remove torn portion in avascular zone; preserve healthy tissue.

Total Meniscectomy: Generally avoided due to increased risk of joint instability and osteoarthritis. (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: A 27-year-old basketball player presents with lateral knee pain after a twisting injury during a game. Physical examination reveals a positive varus stress test. Imaging shows an isolated lateral collateral ligament (LCL) tear with a small bony avulsion. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning objective:
  • ➤ Injury Type Common Cause Severity Treatment Surgical Need MCL Valgus force (inward) Sprains to complete tears Partial tear/ Low grade full-thickness tears: Conservative (bracing) for partial/low-grade tears Yes, for complete tears or chronic instability. LCL Varus force (outward) Often combined with PLC injuries Isolates LCL Injury: Conservative (bracing) (Option A ruled out) Yes, for bony avulsions or PLC injuries. (Option C)
  • ➤ Injury Type Common Cause Severity Treatment Surgical Need
  • ➤ MCL Valgus force (inward) Sprains to complete tears Partial tear/ Low grade full-thickness tears: Conservative (bracing) for partial/low-grade tears Yes, for complete tears or chronic instability.
  • ➤ Valgus force (inward)
  • ➤ Valgus force (inward)
  • ➤ Sprains to complete tears
  • ➤ Sprains to complete tears
  • ➤ Partial tear/ Low grade full-thickness tears: Conservative (bracing) for partial/low-grade tears
  • ➤ Partial tear/ Low grade full-thickness tears: Conservative (bracing) for partial/low-grade tears
  • ➤ Partial tear/ Low grade full-thickness tears:
  • ➤ Yes, for complete tears or chronic instability.
  • ➤ Yes, for complete tears or chronic instability.
  • ➤ complete tears or chronic instability.
  • ➤ LCL Varus force (outward) Often combined with PLC injuries Isolates LCL Injury: Conservative (bracing) (Option A ruled out) Yes, for bony avulsions or PLC injuries. (Option C)
  • ➤ Varus force (outward)
  • ➤ Varus force (outward)
  • ➤ Often combined with PLC injuries
  • ➤ Often combined with PLC injuries
  • ➤ Isolates LCL Injury: Conservative (bracing) (Option A ruled out)
  • ➤ Isolates LCL Injury: Conservative (bracing) (Option A ruled out)
  • ➤ Isolates LCL Injury:
  • ➤ (Option A ruled out)
  • ➤ Yes, for bony avulsions or PLC injuries. (Option C)
  • ➤ Yes, for bony avulsions or PLC injuries. (Option C)
  • ➤ bony avulsions or PLC injuries.

Injury Type

Common Cause

Severity

Treatment

Surgical Need

MCL

Valgus force (inward)

Sprains to complete tears

Partial tear/ Low grade full-thickness tears: Conservative (bracing) for partial/low-grade tears

Yes, for complete tears or chronic instability.

LCL

Varus force (outward)

Often combined with PLC injuries

Isolates LCL Injury: Conservative (bracing) (Option A ruled out)

Yes, for bony avulsions or PLC injuries. (Option C)

questions.text: A 25-year-old male football player presents to the emergency department after sustaining a lateral blow to his knee during a game. He complains of immediate swelling, pain, and instability in the knee. On physical examination, there is tenderness along the medial aspect of the knee and a positive anterior drawer test. Which of the following structures is most likely involved in this type of injury?

options.label: A
options.text: Lateral collateral ligament, anterior cruciate ligament, and lateral meniscus

options.label: B
options.text: Medial collateral ligament, anterior cruciate ligament, and medial meniscus

options.label: C
options.text: Posterior cruciate ligament, medial collateral ligament, and lateral meniscus

options.label: D
options.text: Medial collateral ligament, posterior cruciate ligament, and medial meniscus

questions.correct_answer: B. Medial collateral ligament, anterior cruciate ligament, and medial meniscus
questions.explanation:
Component Affected

Cause of Injury

Result

Medial Collateral Ligament

Valgus force (knee bending inward)

Stretching/Tearing

Anterior Cruciate Ligament

Twisting motion

Rotational instability

Medial Meniscus

Twisting force (medial meniscus less mobile)

Tear due to susceptibility

questions.text: A patient experiences persistent shoulder pain and weakness after a fall. An MRI reveals a full-thickness rotator cuff tear. Which statement correctly describes the classification of rotator cuff tears?

options.label: A
options.text: Full-thickness tears involve bursal side tear, within tendon substance

options.label: B
options.text: Partial-thickness tears can occur on the articular side or bursal side

options.label: C
options.text: Full-thickness tears are typically caused by overuse and repetitive stress

options.label: D
options.text: Partial-thickness tears develop gradually due to impingement

questions.correct_answer: B. Partial-thickness tears can occur on the articular side or bursal side
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Common Causes

Partial-Thickness Tears

Involve damage to some fibers of the tendon; can occur on:

Bursal side (top)

Articular side (bottom)

Within tendon substance (Option A ruled out) (Option B)

Overuse, repetitive stress (Option C ruled out)

Full-Thickness Tears

Complete rupture of the tendon; not attached to the bone

Sudden injuries (e.g., falls), gradual development due to stress or impingement (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with severe left shoulder pain, worsening over weeks, especially when raising her arm. Physical examination reveals weakness in arm abduction and tenderness along the acromion. She cannot maintain maximal external rotation during testing. Which clinical test is most likely to confirm a rotator cuff tear?
questions.explanation:
Examination

Findings

Look

Scars or sinuses in skin, especially in the axilla

Shoulder asymmetry in shape and muscle bulk

Muscle wasting (deltoid, supraspinatus, infraspinatus) indicating possible nerve issues or tears

Swelling in acromioclavicular or sternoclavicular joints

Feel

Check skin temperature (inflammation typically does not affect it)

Palpate bony points (sternoclavicular joint, clavicle, acromioclavicular joint)

Locate bicipital groove

Assess tenderness along acromion (possible tendinitis or tear)

Move

Observe active movements (abduction, flexion, rotation) for symmetry and pain

Conduct passive movements while stabilizing the scapula

Assess strength of shoulder muscles (deltoid, serratus anterior, pectoralis major)

Other Systems

Examine the cervical spine for referred pain

Assess generalized joint laxity

Conduct neurological exam for nerve involvement

Test

Description

Painful Arc (Option B ruled out)

Pain between 60-120° active abduction, relieved by external rotation.

Neer’s Impingement Sign (Option A ruled out)

Passive flexion, abduction, and internal rotation elicit pain.

Neer’s Test for Impingement

Repeating the Neer’s sign post-anesthetic injection confirms diagnosis.

Hawkins-Kennedy Test (Option D ruled out)

Internal rotation with arm at 90° elevation causes anterolateral shoulder pain.

Test

Description

Supraspinatus (Empty Can Test)

Weakness when resisting downward pressure on abducted arms suggests supraspinatus tear.

Infraspinatus (Resisted External Rotation)

Weakness during resisted external rotation indicates infraspinatus weakness.

Subscapularis (Belly Press Test)

Inability to press hand into abdomen indicates subscapularis weakness.

Infraspinatus and Posterior Cuff (Lag and Drop Signs)

Inability to maintain external rotation suggests tears.

Subscapularis (Lift-Off Test) (Option C)

Inability to hold their hand away from their back indicates weakness.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with shoulder pain and limited range of motion after a fall. An X-ray is performed to evaluate for rotator cuff injuries. Which of the following findings would not typically be associated with rotator cuff injuries?

options.label: A
options.text: Erosion and sclerosis at the greater tuberosity

options.label: B
options.text: Upward displacement of the humeral head

options.label: C
options.text: Joint space narrowing of the acromioclavicular joint

options.label: D
options.text: Presence of a well-defined calcific deposit within the deltoid muscle

questions.correct_answer: D. Presence of a well-defined calcific deposit within the deltoid muscle
questions.explanation:
Condition

X-ray Findings

Early Cuff Dysfunction
  • Typically normal X-rays in initial rotator cuff impingement or tendinitis stages.

Chronic Tendinitis
  • Erosion, sclerosis, or cysts at tendon insertion on greater tuberosity (thin sclerosis band).(Option A ruled out)
  • Acromion Changes: Roughening/overgrowth at anterior edge, thinning of the acromion, upward humeral head displacement on caudal tilt view.
  • Acromioclavicular Osteoarthritis: Joint space narrowing, osteophytes, and subchondral sclerosis, especially in older patients. (Option C ruled out)

Cuff Disruption
  • Upward Humeral Head Displacement: Decreased subacromial space due to ineffective stabilization from torn rotator cuff. (Option B ruled out)
  • Glenohumeral Osteoarthritis: Develops from altered mechanics and instability over time.

Acute Calcific Tendinitis
  • Calcification above greater tuberosity in supraspinatus tendon, changing from well-defined to “woolly” during resorption, and may eventually resolve. (Option D)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with shoulder pain and weakness after a fall. Imaging reveals a rotator cuff tear. Which of the following imaging modalities is considered the gold standard for diagnosing intra-articular shoulder pathologies, including rotator cuff tears?
questions.explanation:
Investigation Method

Description

X-rays (Option B ruled out)

Useful for identifying bony abnormalities and calcifications.

Arthrography

Injects contrast into the shoulder joint to visualize the rotator cuff and glenoid labrum; often combined with CT or MRI.

Computed Tomography (CT) (Option D ruled out)

Aids in surgical planning for procedures like shoulder replacement; CT arthrography identifies tears but is largely replaced by MRA.

Ultrasound (Option A ruled out)

Real-time imaging for detecting rotator cuff tears and biceps tendon issues; operator-dependent for interpretation.

Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)

Excellent for visualizing soft tissue structures, assessing tear size, fatty infiltration, and joint evaluation.

Magnetic Resonance Arthrography (MRA) (Option C)

Highly sensitive for detecting labral tears and partial rotator cuff tears using contrast.

Arthroscopy

Minimally invasive procedure for diagnosing and treating intra-articular shoulder pathologies, considered the gold standard.

Condition

Description

Rotator cuff tears

Includes partial or full-thickness tears.

Labral detachments

Includes SLAP lesions.

Impingement syndrome

Affects shoulder movement and pain.

Frozen shoulder (adhesive capsulitis)

Restricted shoulder mobility.

Treatment Option

Description

Activity Modification

Avoid activities that worsen pain, particularly those in the "impingement position."

Physiotherapy

Focus on strengthening rotator cuff muscles, scapular stability, and shoulder range of motion.

Medications

NSAIDs reduce pain/inflammation; corticosteroid injections provide temporary relief.

Extracorporeal Shockwave Therapy

Treats calcific tendinitis; less effective than needle aspiration or surgery.

Needle Aspiration and Irrigation (Barbotage)

Ultrasound-guided procedure to remove calcific deposits; effective in acute cases.

Surgical Procedure

Description

Open Acromioplasty

Involves removing part of the acromion to reduce impingement; largely replaced by arthroscopic methods.

Arthroscopic Acromioplasty

Minimally invasive procedure with smaller incisions, less tissue disruption, and faster recovery.

Open Rotator Cuff Repair

Reattaches torn tendon to humerus; requires longer recovery.

Arthroscopic Rotator Cuff Repair

Minimally invasive; faster rehabilitation and less postoperative pain.

Biceps Tenodesis

Reattaches the long head of the biceps tendon for stability.

SLAP Lesion Repair

Arthroscopic procedure to repair superior labrum tears; may involve biceps tenodesis.

Capsular Release (for Frozen Shoulder)

Releases contracted capsular tissue to improve range of motion.
